explanation: Explanation
Linux is an open-source Unix-like operating system kernel.
Linus Torvalds created the Linux kernel in 1991.
Tux the penguin is the official mascot of Linux.
A Linux distribution (distro) is an OS made from Linux kernel + software packages.
Ubuntu

question_text: What is the terminal in Linux?
explanation: A text-based interface to interact with the Linux system using commands.

question_text: What is a shell in Linux?
explanation: A shell is a command-line interpreter that executes user commands.

question_text: What is the most common Linux shell?
explanation: Bash (Bourne Again SHell) is the most common default shell.
The root user is the superuser with administrative privileges.
SuperUser DO - allows users to run commands with root privileges.
pwd (Print Working Directory) shows the current directory path.

question_text: How to list files in a directory?
explanation: ls lists files and directories in the current folder.
ls -l shows files in long format with details like permissions
ls -a shows all files including hidden files (starting with .).
cd (Change Directory) - moves to specified directory.

question_text: How to go to home directory?
explanation: cd ~ or just cd - goes to the user's home directory.

question_text: How to go to parent directory?
explanation: cd .. moves to the parent directory (one level up).
mkdir directory_name creates a new directory.
mkdir -p dir1/dir2/dir3 creates parent directories as needed.

question_text: How to remove an empty directory?
explanation: rmdir directory_name removes an empty directory.

question_text: How to remove a directory with files?
explanation: rm -r directory_name removes directory and all its contents recursively.
touch filename creates an empty file.
cp source_file destination_file copies a file.
cp -r source_directory destination copies a directory recursively.
mv old_name new_name moves or renames files/directories.
rm filename deletes a file.
cat filename displays the entire file content.

question_text: How to view file page by page?
explanation: less filename views file page by page (press q to quit).
head filename shows first 10 lines of a file.
tail filename shows last 10 lines of a file.

question_text: How to follow log file updates?
explanation: tail -f filename shows last lines and follows updates in real-time.
find /path -name "filename" searches for files.

question_text: How to search text in files?
explanation: grep "pattern" filename searches for text pattern in files.

question_text: How to search case-insensitive with grep?
explanation: grep -i "pattern" filename searches case-insensitive.

question_text: How to count lines in a file?
explanation: wc -l filename counts lines in a file.
df -h shows disk space usage in human-readable format.
du -sh directory_name shows directory size in human-readable format.
ps aux shows all running processes.
kill PID terminates a process by its Process ID.

question_text: How to force kill a process?
explanation: kill -9 PID forcefully kills a process.
top shows real-time system processes and resource usage.
uname -a shows all system information.
free -h shows memory usage in human-readable format.
ip addr show or ifconfig shows network interface and IP address.
ping hostname checks network connectivity to a host.

question_text: How to download files from internet?
explanation: wget URL downloads files from the internet.

question_text: How to extract a tar file?
explanation: tar -xvf filename.tar extracts tar archive.

question_text: How to create a tar archive?
explanation: tar -cvf archive.tar files/ creates a tar archive.
gzip filename compresses a file (creates filename.gz).
gunzip filename.gz decompresses a gzip file.
history shows previously executed commands.
clear clears the terminal screen.
man command shows manual pages for commands.
whatis command shows one-line description of a command.

question_text: How to get help for a command?
explanation: command --help or -h shows help for that command.
chmod permissions filename changes file permissions.
chmod 755 sets rwxr-xr-x permissions (owner: read/write/execute
chmod +x filename adds execute permission to file.
chown user filename changes file owner.
chgrp group filename changes file group.

question_text: What are Linux file permissions numbers?
explanation: 4=read
644 = rw-r--r-- (owner: read/write
/ is the root directory - top of the filesystem hierarchy.
/home contains user home directories.
/etc contains system configuration files.
/var contains variable data like logs
/tmp contains temporary files (cleared on reboot).
/bin contains essential binary executables (commands).
/usr contains user programs
/dev contains device files (hardware as files).
/proc contains process and system information (virtual filesystem).
A symbolic link (symlink) is a shortcut to another file/directory.

question_text: How to create a symbolic link?
explanation: ln -s target link_name creates a symbolic link.
A hard link is another name for the same file data (same inode).

question_text: How to create a hard link?
explanation: ln target link_name creates a hard link.
PATH is an environment variable listing directories where executables are searched.
env or printenv shows all environment variables.

question_text: How to set an environment variable?
explanation: export VARIABLE=value sets an environment variable.
.bashrc is a shell script that runs when Bash shell starts (user-specific).

question_text: How to edit a text file in terminal?
explanation: nano filename opens file in nano text editor.
vi is a powerful text editor in Linux (visual editor).

question_text: How to save and exit vi?
explanation: Press ESC
topic: then :wq to save and quit vi editor.

question_text: How to quit vi without saving?
explanation: Press ESC
topic: then :q! to quit vi without saving.

explanation: vim (Vi IMproved) is an enhanced version of vi editor.

question_text: How to update package list in Ubuntu?
explanation: sudo apt update updates the package list.

question_text: How to install a package in Ubuntu?
explanation: sudo apt install package_name installs a package.

question_text: How to remove a package in Ubuntu?
explanation: sudo apt remove package_name removes a package.
yum is the package manager for Red Hat
sudo yum install package_name installs a package (RHEL/CentOS).
cron is a time-based job scheduler in Linux.
crontab -e edits user's cron jobs.
A daemon is a background service process in Linux.
uptime shows how long system has been running.
sudo shutdown -h now shuts down the system.
sudo reboot or sudo shutdown -r now reboots the system.
uname -r shows kernel version.
lsb_release -a shows Linux distribution details.
SSH (Secure Shell) is a protocol for secure remote access to Linux systems.
ssh username@hostname connects to remote host via SSH.
scp file user@host:path securely copies files between hosts.
zip archive.zip file1 file2 creates zip archive.
unzip archive.zip extracts zip archive.
diff file1 file2 shows differences between files.
sort filename sorts lines in a file alphabetically.
uniq filename removes duplicate consecutive lines.
| (pipe) sends output of one command as input to another command.
> redirects output to a file (overwrites).
>> redirects output to a file (appends).

question_text: How to run command in background?
explanation: command & runs command in background.
nohup command & runs command immune to hangups (continues after logout).
type command shows if command is alias
alias short='long command' creates command shortcut.
alias ll='ls -la' creates alias for ls -la.
Add alias to ~/.bashrc file for permanent alias.
#! (shebang) at script start specifies interpreter (e.g.
chmod +x script.sh makes script executable.

question_text: How to run a shell script?
explanation: ./script.sh runs script in current directory.
